Former Cats read into Pitino's post-UNCW rant

Former Cats read into Pitino's post-UNCW rant

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 10:59 a.m. EST December 17, 2014

Then-Kentucky coach Rick Pitino orchestrates his team's offense from the sidelines during the first half of a Jan. 20, 1996 game against TCU.(Photo: AP Photo/Ed Reinke)

3 CONNECT 12 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

A number of former University of Kentucky basketball players can sympathize this week with current Louisville counterparts, because they know what coach Rick Pitino's thoughts on the Cardinals' 68-57 win Sunday over UNC Wilmington mean moving forward.

Part of what Pitino said "I'm very, very upset at our basketball team, and they'll pay the consequences tomorrow" resonated with Cameron Mills, who tweeted that he "got shivers reading that quote."

For Mills' UK team, Pitino going off after a 12-point win over Georgia in 1995 meant a midnight practice.

"In '95 those were the most nervous 8 hours of my life waiting for 12:01AM," Mills added.

Mills got some other former Wildcats in on the conversation, too. Said Allen Edwards: "Yes one of my greatest stories."

Scott Padgett added that the midnight practice fell during Nazr Mohammed's UK visit, and that "would have scared most recruits away."

Then Mohammed, who went on to a lengthy NBA career after playing at UK, chimed in, tweeting, "remember it like it was yesterday. One of the best decisions of my life."

So, what happened at the midnight practice? It was, in fact, after a Jan. 14, 1995 game against Georgia an 83-71 Cats win.

Said Mills: "film session then brutal, 3 hour practice. In bed at 4:30AM. National Championship 1year later."

Story continues below the video

Pitino takes two questions at postgame press conference after win and then leaves. This is the complete 100-second press conference. Jeff Greer

IN THE C-J

Recruiting reporter Steve Jones is rolling all day Wednesday with updates from the midyear recruiting period, when a number of junior college prospects are expected to sign with U of L and UK. Already, schools are announcing their players this morning. (http://cjky.it/1AF9GQP)

UK beat writer Kyle Tucker checked in with NBA draft experts following Willie Cauley-Stein's performance against North Carolina and found, to no surprise, the junior's stock is rising. "For the first two years, his projection as a late lottery pick was based almost completely on what we thought he could be some day, and now we're seeing all of that come together," said ESPN's Chad Ford. (http://cjky.it/1uST7fX)

Writing from Tuesday's pre-Belk Bowl availability with U of L head coach Bobby Petrino and his two coordinators, columnist Tim Sullivan said he believes it when Petrino insists he hasn't selected a quarterback for the Dec. 30 game because "here, it is the system that is the star." (http://cjky.it/1uST83s)

AROUND THE WEB

John Calipari suggested to a Washington Post reporter, in a story published this week, that just 10 or 15 of the Cats' games this year will challenge his team more than a regular practice. So The Post's Adam Kilgore witnessed one of those practices, providing an inside look at what he labeled "one of the fiercest, most intense games of this college basketball season." (http://wapo.st/1GqNMEW)

Former U of L commit Antonio Blakeney, who's now considering UK along with LSU, Missouri, North Carolina and N.C. State, told Adam Zagoria that his decision could come soon, at least if the timing is up to his mother. "I kind of want to do it late, but my mom may want me to get it over with," he said. "I think I'm going to talk to her after City of Palms (a tournament in Florida) and figure it out." (http://bit.ly/1uSTeIq)

A Twitter user re-imagined the College Football Playoff as a system that includes all 128 FBS schools, and in that bracket Brian Fremeau matched up U of L and UK in the first round. After the Cards took that one, though, they ran into top-seeded Florida State which, of course, went on to the Final Four. (http://usat.ly/1BYio0S)

Jonathan Lintner can be reached at (502) 582-4199. Follow him on Twitter @JonathanLintner.
